document_data.name: Temple of Bane
document_data.organizations: Organizations in the Temple of Bane (Bezantur)
document_data.mainbody: The '''Temple of Bane''' in [[Bezantur]] was the center of [[Thayan]] worship of [[Bane]] in the 14{{th}} century [[DR]].
document_data.Location: The temple was located in eastern-central Bezantur, the so-called "City of a Thousand Temples." Appropriately, it was surrounded by other temples, namely the much larger [[House of Cyric (Bezantur)|House of Cyric]] (formerly a temple of [[Bhaal]]) and the [[Temple of Tempus (Bezantur)|Temple of Tempus]] to the west, the [[Temple of Talos (Bezantur)|Temple of Talos]] to the north, the grand [[Temple of Kossuth (Bezantur)|Temple of Kossuth]] to the east, and the [[Temple of Tyr (Bezantur)|Temple of Tyr]] and [[Temple of Lloth (Bezantur)|Temple of Lolth]] to the south.
document_data.Structure: The temple was a well-maintained, jet-black building.
document_data.Activities: The temple hosted religious services to Bane
document_data.History:
Prior to the [[Time of Troubles]], not only did all other temples of Bane in Thay report to the high priest of the temple in Bezantur, but the the Thayan clergies of [[church of Bhaal|Bhaal]], [[church of Iyachtu Xvim|Iyachtu Xvim]], and [[church of Loviatar|Loviatar]] did as well. The [[Red Wizards]] were wary of the temple as they suspected it was an ally of the [[Zhentarim]].

In the {{YearlinkName|1357}}, the high priest of the temple had begun to see the Red Wizards as blasphemers who would strive to become [[god]]s themselves rather than submit to Bane. He called upon Bane to punish these heathens, and in response, [[Iyachtu Xvim]] himself was tasked with inserting himself into the Thayan power struggles to begin smiting the Red Wizards.

Following Bane's death in the {{YearlinkName|1358}}, the dead [[god]]'s popularity remained high enough that a small contingent of [[priest]]s continued to maintain the temple and to pray for his return, even leading ceremonies in his name.
document_data.Inhabitants: In the mid–14{{th}} century DR, the high priest was an influential figure who was believed to be an agent of [[Zhentil Keep]]. As of the late 1360s DR, the temple was headed by a high priestess named [[Cothra]] who actually worshiped [[Iyachtu Xvim]].
